moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3
comment:
Another good
idea here is to play d4. These pawns make it easier to control the center. 2.
d4 e5 3.d5 White has firm control of the center. The center is important
because if you lose the center then you lose the game.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3
comment:
Developing
your pieces is good. Objectively this is not the best move but this develops
good habits for the novice player.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5
comment:
This is the move I like because it
gains all sorts of space in the center. The move also prepares to attack on
the Kingside because of the space that is gained there. 3...e5 Welcome to the
"Four Knights". The reason we have these names is to help us identify common
opening sequences. Once you learn these names then you can find them in books
and study them until you know them. At this point, just enjoy the King hunt.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5
comment:
This is a error. There are several reasons for this judgment.
First, the Knight and the Bishop are of equal value. Your Bishop move does not
really immediately threaten anything. Finally, the Knight on the rim is
severely restricted in its movement. As you get better you will find
exceptions to the rule for concrete reasons. But for now remember, "a Knight
on the rim is dim."

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5
comment: Good! You removed the defender and now you pick up the piece.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6
comment:
This is not
a good place for the Bishop because it blocks the advance of the d-pawn. If
the d-pawn is blocked then the Queen Bishop will have difficulty developing
properly.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4
comment:
5.d4 does the same thing and completes the control in the
center. I distrust this move because if you castle Kingside the g1-a7 diagonal
is open to all sorts of mischief.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3
comment:
This move is not
correct. First, it gives back material ...Bxf4. Second it signals a retreat
from the center. Remember that when your Knight crosses the 4/5 line, you want
to maximize the damage it causes before retreating back into your own
territory.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6
comment: A blunder, that you nicely point out.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5
comment:
Nice! One of
the basic move in the "how to humiliate your opponent 101" class. The idea
behind this is repeated through the GM level. The pawns being the "weakest"
(read "least valuable", because they are the "least mobile") become the
strongest (since they can make contact, threats, and do battle where others
fear to tread!

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4
1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4
comment: Another mistake because of 13.Nfg5 Qe5 14.Qxh5

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5
comment:
Chasing the unguarded Bishop on a6. This is a "one move" attack. For the
novice, it's ok. However, I'd like to push you to deepen your thought process
and think at least one move deeper. One problem with the "one move" attack is
that it often does not take into account the opponent's threatsandpossibilitie
s. Another problem is that better moves are typically available.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1
comment:
Always play with a plan. As yourself what your opponent is threatening and
what you are threatening.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4
comment: Nxa6

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5
comment:
Your Knight is
much more useful than the Knight on a5. Do not trade useful pieces for useless
pieces, even if they are of equal value.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+
comment: Remember this diagonal? It is trouble, all started by the move f4.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4
comment:
A mistake, but an interesting idea. You recognize the power of the
Bishop pair. The giving of the pawn frees the Queen Bishop. A much stronger
idea to free the Bishop is to play a4. [19.a4 b4 20.c3 Nf4 21.cxb4 and the
Bishops are free.]

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1
comment:
Repeat after me.... "ATTACK!" "Fischer's
rule" was attack something if it doesn't move take it. Unless you there are
specific reasons you must attack. [20.Bf5 Ree8 21.Bxc8 Rxc8 22.cxb5 cxb5 Being
a piece up gives you the luxury of opening the game up. Typically the open
nature will favor the player that is best developed (or has the most material.)
]

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1 Rh6 21. g4
comment:
OK, I've got to complain about this move. The move d4
attacks the Queen (at c5) with the pawn and the Rook (at h6) with the Bishop
at the same time. The basic idea of the combination is to attack two things at
the same time.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1 Rh6 21. g4 Ng3+ 22. Kg2 Nxf1 23. g5 Rxh2+
comment: Missing a force mate. 23...Bh3+ 24.Kh1 Qf2 and there is no stopping Qg2 mate!

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1 Rh6 21. g4 Ng3+ 22. Kg2 Nxf1 23. g5 Rxh2+ 24. Nxh2 Nxh2 25. Qh1
comment:
You needed Qc2. This move allow Black an advantage
with ...Qd4 or ...g6 or ...Re8 or ...f5. You get the point.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1 Rh6 21. g4 Ng3+ 22. Kg2 Nxf1 23. g5 Rxh2+ 24. Nxh2 Nxh2 25. Qh1 f6 26. Qxh2 fxg5

1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1 Rh6 21. g4 Ng3+ 22. Kg2 Nxf1 23. g5 Rxh2+ 24. Nxh2 Nxh2 25. Qh1 f6 26. Qxh2 fxg5 27. Bxh7+ Kf7 28. Ba3 Qxa3 29. Qc7+ Kf6 30. Rf1+ Bf5 31. Rxf5+ Ke6 32. Qxc6+
comment: The reason for Ba3.

moves: 1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e5 4. Bb5 Na5 5. Nxe5 Bd6 6. f4 c6 7. Bd3 b5 8. Nf3 Ba6 9. e5 Nh5 10. exd6 Qf6 11. O-O Qxd6 12. Ne4 Qxf4 13. Qe2 O-O 14. Nc5 Rae8 15. Qd1 Qd6 16. b4 Bc8 17. bxa5 Qxc5+ 18. Kh1 d5 19. c4 Re6 20. Bb1 Rh6 21. g4 Ng3+ 22. Kg2 Nxf1 23. g5 Rxh2+ 24. Nxh2 Nxh2 25. Qh1 f6 26. Qxh2 fxg5 27. Bxh7+ Kf7 28. Ba3 Qxa3 29. Qc7+ Kf6 30. Rf1+ Bf5 31. Rxf5+ Ke6 32. Qxc6+ Qd6 33. cxd5+ Ke7
comment:
And White gets to take all
Black's remaining pieces, if you want them. 27...Kf7 28.Bb2 d4 29.Bg6+ Ke6 30.
Re1+ Kd6 31.Qxg7 Rf4 32.Re8 32.Qe7# That's check mate. 32...Rg4+ 33.Kf3 Rg1 34.
Bxd4 34.Qe7# That's check mate. 34...Qa3+ 35.Kf2 Re1 Black misses mate in two
with.... 35...Qg3+ 36.Ke2 Now pick one either ...Re1 or Bg4 is check mate. 36.
Rxe1 36.Rd8+ Ke6 Pick one 37.Qf6 or 37.Qf7 are both mate. 36...bxc4 37.Be5+ 37.
Qe7+ Kd5 38.Qe5# That's check mate. 37...Kd5 38.Be4+ Kc5 OK, we are into the
territory where "anything" wins. I suppose it could be argued that it doesn't
matter, but I do not like to see a student go to sleep at this point in the
game. When the point is in hand, don't lose it! Like you almost did when Black
missed ...Qg3+ a couple of moves back. 39.Rb1 Bg4 Qxa7, Qe7 and Qf8 are all
check mate. 40.Qb7 Qxa5 41.Qxc6# 1-0
